10003.description: GO Project’s GO School Saturday Volunteer Tutor: Job Description GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity, or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of 2-4 students on the lesson, providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1st-8th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session (Session I: October-December, Session II: January-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - support instruction and engagement Help prepare, record, and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding students’ progress and/or concerns, and with the Senior Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience Time Commitment Session II: January-April 2018; 14 Saturdays from 9:00AM-12:45PM Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. We will honor preferences when possible. GO Fundamentals Tutoring: How YOU Can Help GO Fundamentals, is a tutoring program for GO Project K-8 students who have been identified as \"promotion in doubt\" by their public schools. (Promotion in Doubt means a student may need to repeat their current grade). GO Fundamentals provides the students with additional academic time on literacy development. By working with the students on a more individualized basis, we will give them more opportunities to master the reading and writing skills needed to be promoted to the next grade in June. 10003.description: We are currently looking for Volunteer Office Assistants to work in the afternoon and/or the evening. Volunteer Office Assistants serve 4-6 hours per week for a prestigious downtown NYC community theater that produces 25-30 new plays and 3 free community events each year. Volunteer Office Assistants will answer phones, take reservations, file papers and occasionally assist Executive Director Crystal Field by writing letters or researching on the internet. Opportunities available specifically on weekdays in the Morning/Afternoons from 10am to 4pm, or in the evenings from 4pm to 10pm, or on weekends from 12pm to 8pm. Volunteers will receive FREE tickets to all TNC productions.

10003.title: Help a Child Love to Learn: Volunteer Tutor with GO Project!

10003.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Chinese (both Mandarin and Cantonese) in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Chinese speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak both Mandarin and Cantonese is preferred. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.

10003.title: Saturday Chinese Translators Needed!

10003.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. 10003.title: Help a Child Love to Learn: Volunteer Tutor with GO Project!

10003.description: GO Project Spanish Translator (Saturday Volunteer) GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO School is a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Spanish in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Spanish speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak Spanish. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.

07901.description: Founded in 1912, Girl Scouts of the USA is the preeminent organization for girls with a current membership of 3.6 million girls and adults. Volunteers use their expertise, skills, interests, and life experience to shape fun and enriching leadership experiences for girls and inspire them to reach their personal best. Girl Scouts Heart of New Jersey is looking for a Service Unit Manager to oversee Girl Scouts in the Summit community. As the Service Unit Manager, you will oversee the \"business\" of the service unit. With the help of council staff and your team of volunteers, you will work to grow Girl Scouts in Summit. Responsibilities include: Attend training to learn the job and participate in ongoing learning opportunities for continuous growth in the position Work in partnership with council staff to support leaders in your community Create an annual plan of action that includes leader meetings, girl and leader events, recruitment activities and financial planning Recruit and evaluate all Service Unit team members Oversee and support adult members in the Service Unit Team Support to all volunteers through a variety of communication methods Coordinate recruitments to recruit volunteers and girls reflective of the diverse community Create progressive opportunities to engage girls and adults within the Service Unit Qualifications: Computer Skills: Access to e-mail and the internet Excellent organization skills Excellent verbal and written communication skills Men are welcome! No previous Girl Scout experience needed. Training is provided Benefits: Develop leadership skills in a supportive, fun environment Volunteer around your schedule. No minimum hours required. Make a difference in the lives of girls Gain transferable skills in management, budgeting, and group dynamics Access to learning opportunities that only volunteers have access to
07901.title: Want to develop leadership skills while having fun?
07901.org: Girl Scouts Heart of New Jersey

07465.description: Hello, Our day care center needs a new, hospital-grade, floor - both subfloor and flooring - about 23 x 43 square. Both material and labor needed! Weekends, holidays - when the children are not here. Overnight if no fumes. Please call 862.200.5125. Thank you.
07465.title: Flooring installation expert

07465.description: We want murals - paint, collage, etc. - for our Day Care and residential areas. Please call Betsy at 862.200.5125. Thank you.
07465.title: Artist

07004.description: Embrace Relief is a 501 (c) (3) non-profit organization that brings together teams of volunteers to collaborate on humanitarian aid and disaster relief efforts. These groups provide an array of support, offering to assist financially, emotionally, and physically with the needs of families and communities ravaged by disaster. The foundation collects, delivers and distributes supplies and resources to families, individuals, and institutions in different countries. Embrace Relief is planning to start a new project. Everyone has a role in Embrace Relief. The organization is looking for volunteers for three months starting in January. Embrace Relief needs assistance in developing and contributing to public relations and marketing activities
07004.title: Public Relations

10474.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10474.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 48 Joseph R. Drake, NYC)

10471.description: Join us in celebrating 2,500 New York City students as they showcase and put to test their self-designed robots with the hopes of advancing to the 2018 FIRST World Championships. We need robot judges, referees, queuers, and more. No experience required! In the spirit of Gracious Professionalism, enjoy free catered cuisine, fun dance music, and awesome swag giveaways as we work together in service to the next generation of STEM entrepreneurs.
10471.title: Volunteer at a LEGO Robotics competition @ Horace Mann

10472.description: Volunteers are needed at the following locations to help facilitate the \"We Are New York\" conversation program for Intermediate English learners.
10472.title: CONVERSATION GROUP FACILITATOR

11226.description: Work with Adult Literacy Students at one of the five Brooklyn Public Library Learning Centers. Help them reach their personal goals. Lead reading and writing activities for small groups of adult learners who read below the fifth grade level. Assist them in using technology. We provide a 20 hour Volunteer Tutor Training where you will learn the BPL’s Literacy Program’s philosophy, how to use the library’s resources for instruction, and how to create effective lesson plans. Professional staff will encourage your development in this richly rewarding field. Volunteers must have a high school diploma or equivalent and a love of reading and writing. Volunteers are asked for a one year commitment to tutoring either 2 - 2 hours sessions, or 1 - 3-hour session per week. To learn more about the Brooklyn Public Library Learning Centers, please visit the BPL website at http://www.bklynpubliclibrary.org . To register to attend a Volunteer Information Session, please click here.
11226.title: Volunteer Tutor Information Session
11226.org: The Learning Centers @ Brooklyn Public Library

06902.description: Our amazing volunteer Book Lady has given away over 40,000 books since she started filling our 2 community carts three years ago. Are you free Monday mornings between 10 and 11:30 to help haul boxes a few feet, place books on the shelves, and have fun with a a couple dozen three year olds who visit the carts. Not only is it a dream volunteer job, but Book Lady Lorrie is as wonderful as they come.
06902.title: Help our Book Lady on Monday Mornings

06902.description: We have a few retired veterans here at Brighton Gardens of Stamford who would like to share their stories with people. Not much is required other than interest and spending 45 minutes per week with them and even that is flexible. Call or email if you are interested. Thank you!
06902.title: Any local Veterans out there willing to come in and spend time with retirees?

06903.description: Historic Home Docent & Museum Greeter We are looking for volunteers who would like to introduce visitors to our 1699 historic house museum, The Hoyt-Barnum House. You would be involved with greeting visitors with a smile and giving a brief explanation of the Center's offerings: a research library, photo archive, our current exhibit, and our historic house museum. People who wish to tour Hoyt-Barnum House first view an introductory film before starting the audio tour. You would be responsible for selling tickets and recording transactions, giving guests their audio pods and collecting them after the tours, opening and closing up the house museum, and monitoring visitors while they are in the house. Training is provided. Museum Docents should be friendly and personable. They should be physically able to manage stairs and brief walks on a regular basis. Docents should be at least 20 years old and able to work at least one four-hour day, 2 x /month. Docents are needed for Thursdays and Fridays. Shifts are from noon to 3:15 pm on Thursdays and Fridays. Two docents are needed on Saturday: one from 10:30 - 1:00 and one from1:00 to 3:30 pm. You are welcome to stay longer to meet our other volunteers and make use of our facility. Check out our Website for loads of fun information: http://stamfordhistory.org/ Skills Customer Service Public Speaking General Education Problem Solving Communication Basic math/money skills Hope to hear from you soon! Tom Tom Porter Volunteer Coordinator & Board Member Stamford History Center 1508 High Ridge Road Stamford, CT 06903 www.stamfordhistory.org volunteer@stamfordhistory.org (O) 203-329-1183 (C) 917-701-3572
06903.title: Tour Guide & Greeter: Historic Home

06903.description: Assistant Treasurer with the following duties: Reviews weekly cash deposits Receive, organize and pay bills Input accounting activity into Quickbooks Closing accounting books on monthly, quarterly and annual basis Organizing and archiving financial records Hours are flexible: Thursday, Fridays & Saturdays between 10:00 and 12:00 If you fit the bill and would like to help us, please get in touch with me. Thanks for your interest! Tom Porter Volunteer Coordinator - Board Member Stamford History Center 1508 High Ridge Road Stamford, CT 06903 www.stamfordhistory.org volunteer@stamfordhistory.org (O) 203-329-1183 (C) 917-701-3572
06903.title: Assistant Treasurer / Bookeeper

06903.description: Media/News Writer Volunteer, If you enjoy writing, this is the volunteer job for you. We are looking for someone to create press releases about the Stamford History Center for distribution to various media outlets (onlinenews sites, radio, tv, magazines, etc.). You will interview people in the organization to gather information. Once your article is reviewed by our volunteer editors, it will be sent out. It is essential that our media volunteer stays up-to- date with our activities, so press releases go out in a timely fashion. The position can be expanded to include the creation of newsletters and flyers (working with our graphic designer). This is a job that can be done largely from your own laptop/desktop, and at your own convenience. REQUIREMENT: Please write a two or three paragraph \"Press Release\" on one of the following topics: 1] About our Tag Sale 2] The opening of the Hoyt-Barnum House or 3] A past Historical Center event You can get ideas by going to our web site: www.stamfordhistory.org Forward it to me and we will review and get back to you. Thanks again for your interest in joining the volunteer team! Tom Tom Porter Volunteer Coordinator Stamford History Center 1508 High Ridge Road Stamford, CT 06903 www.stamfordhistory.org 203-329-1183 Skills needed: organized, experienced writer; a self-starter who can use Word and navigate the internet.
06903.title: Media/News Writer Volunteer

06901.description: Stamford Academy serves about 135 high school students who have been unsuccessful within the traditional school model. The ratio of students with Individual Education Plans (IEP) is about twice the rate of Stamford Public Schools, yet Stamford is able to provide only one SPED teacher. You know how important one-on-one instruction is. Do you have a couple of hours to spare once a week during the school year to help tutor a student? Training provided. To meet our kids is to love them. They are wary and giving; have big dreams and struggle to stay on task; are talented and funny; and may have not had dinner the night before. If you'd like to know more, please contact me.
06901.title: Do you know what an IEP is? If so, read on...

They are wary and giving; have big dreams and struggle to stay on task; are talented and funny; and may have not had dinner the night before. If you'd like to know more, please contact me.
06901.title: Retired SPED Teachers & Para Educators Wanted

10466.title: School Social Worker

The Event Committee includes several leadership positions which will give interns experience in the areas of event planning, public relations, marketing and fundraising! Positions include Event Planner Supervisor Event Program Planner Event Public Relations Manager Event Fundraiser Specialist Event Committee Member Please sign up by completing the link below: https://goo.gl/forms/LcuvmOqnzauknnAi2
10466.title: Event Committee Planner

10467.description: Help invest in the life of a child by becoming a A Elementary Group Teacher with our Early Scholars Saturday Academy! Teach grades K-6, develop lesson plans, test students, grading & More! Be a part of something great and volunteer today!
10467.title: Elementary Group Teacher

10467.description: Gain exceptional skills in administration, office management and clerical work by volunteering with I'RAISE Girls & Boys International. Bi-Weekly Stipend of $200.00 Hours are flexible. College Students are welcome!
10467.title: Administrator

10463.description: Photographer for Mathcounts in the Bronx, a math competition of Bronx Middle school students to be held at Manhattan College on Feb 6, 2018 from 3PM to 7PM. Photos will be uploaded to any public accessible online photo sharing website. Photos will be property of photographer who will allow Mathcounts participants and sponsors to use for publicity
10463.title: Photographer for Math Competition at Manhattan College

10463.description: Volunteers needed 2pm to 7pm to help proctor and grade Middle School Math competition - no math expertise required. Mathcounts is a competition similar to the National Spelling Bee. Top finishers from this competition advance to the NYS competition where the top finishers advance to the National Mathcounts Championship. Your opportunity to help youngsters further their interest in Math. Enjoy the \"Lightning Round\" where the top competitors face off in a \"Jeopardy\" style face to face competition. No Math skills needed, but if you have an interest in Math, challenege yourself as the questions are displayed in the Lightning Round. Two of the volunteers are needed to help with setup starting 1:30pm and cleanup for 30 minutes following conclusion of event - please indicate if available for either. Thank you for your interest.
10463.title: Mathcounts in the Bronx

10463.description: The Special Needs Program at the Kingsbridge Heights Community Center is designed to provide students with the same opportunities as all children in New York City, from fitness to creative spaces. We are looking for volunteers to help with our Respite After School Program on Mondays and Wednesdays between the hours of 3:15 pm and 5:30 pm. The 3:15 pm - 4 pm would be for volunteers who are interested in running arts and crafts activities, but between 4 and 5:30 pm could be for volunteers interested in helping with homework, or run gym activities.
10463.title: Special Needs After-School Volunteer

10463.description: Position Statement: Evening classes, 6:00pm-9:30pm Monday - Thursday The ESOL (English Students of Other Languages) Program Assistant will be responsible for one-on-one support to students during classroom English lesson plans, administrative support to the instructor/s, and technical aspects of assisting students with progressing computer-based language programs. Duties and Responsibilities: Provide participants with one-on-one assistance Assist with technical and administrative tasks Provide administrative back-up and support to ESOL Instructor Engage and retain students by developing supportive relationships Other duties as assigned by Instructor Qualifications: HS Diploma; Some college preferred Comfort with computer applications and data entry Available evening hours Organized, efficient, and task oriented English/Spanish Bi-lingual helpful
10463.title: ESOL Program Volunteer

10460.description: Ariva is a Non-Profit tax Organization that does taxes for the lower-income households in all 5 boroughs. Volunteer Income tax assistants have the opportunity to receive IRS certified tax training, and upon completion of the test, their primary duties will be preparing tax returns. Alternative activities include, intake (help with customer service) and data entry (the IRS requires us to take polls of all of our customers). There are 12 sites located mostly in the Bronx, and Manhattan. We have morning, evening, and weekend hours with no problem working around your schedule and getting you into your preferred location. LET'S HELP OUT OUR COMMUNITY TOGETHER!!
10460.title: Volunteer Income Tax Assistant

10460.description: We are currently recruiting adult volunteers (21+) for Spring 2018! Applicants will be invited to an information session and group interview in January or February. We have many different ways you can participate in our volunteer program. Our volunteer specialties offer something for everyone: AMBASSADOR Our Ambassadors have the important role of greeting zoo visitors, helping them to find their way, and sharing \"what’s happening today!\" (2 day training, 8+ hour a month commitment) WCS NOW Our WCS Now Interpreters facilitate interactive, conservation based activities around the zoo. For this role, we are looking for volunteers that are committed to sharing the WCS mission and message, are outgoing and approachable, are comfortable interacting with large groups, and are eager to learn and try new things. (6 day training, plus online courses, 12+ hour a month commitment) EXPEDITION LEADER Expedition Leaders at the Bronx Zoo lead inquiry-based tours for school children, private groups, families, or other pre-registered participants. If you have a passion for engaging people in observation and critical thinking, are an excellent listener with a strong interest in inquiry, are comfortable managing groups of all sizes, and have a commitment to teaching in response to learner feedback-the Expedition Leader role would be a great fit for you! (*Now Interpreter training a prerequisite, 2 day training, 12+ hour a month commitment) PLAY PARTNER As a Play Partner, you will facilitate nature play based activities in our new Nature Trek exhibit, as well as alongside our Conservation Educators and Fellows during Nature Club events and meetings. If you enjoy spending time outside and embracing all the elements, consider becoming a Play Partner volunteer! (1 day training, 12+ hour a month commitment) EDUCATION ASSISTANT As an Education Assistant, you may greet groups as they arrive to the zoo and guide them to their classrooms, provide support to our Conservation Educators during programs or activities, or assist with family programs, birthday parties, or summer camps! (2 day training, 12 + hours a month commitment). ON-CALL EVENT SUPPORT If you’re interested in volunteering at the Bronx Zoo, but have limited time to commit, consider joining us as an On-Call Event Support Volunteer! You’ll be called upon to help with special events throughout the year. (Online training, 1-2 events per year) To learn more, and apply, visit bronxzoo.com/volunteering

07076.description: Tuesday Mornings Learn How to Save a Life Have you ever been told you are a Good Listener ? Do you have a yearning to Really Make a Difference ? Become a Caring and Crisis Hotline Volunteer Listener. Join our listening community. You could save a life. Volunteers receive 52 hours of comprehensive classroom training in active listening, Mental Health First Aid and Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training. You will also get 24 hours of practice answering calls with the support of seasoned listeners before you answer calls on your own. And, once you are a certified listener, we provide a range of support and training opportunities so you can continue to develop your skills. The training includes Mental Health First Aid and ASIST (Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training) certifications. Join our Tuesday morning training : March 13, 2018 - June 12, 2018 Tuesday mornings 9:30 am - 12:30 pm Plus one full weekend: June 2 and 3, 2018 Congregation Beth Israel 18 Shalom Way, Scotch Plains, NJ 07076 Registration is limited. Register Now! To learn more and apply, please log onto http://caringcontact.org/volunteer-listener-application/ or call 908.301.1899
07076.title: Become a Caring and Crisis Hotline Volunteer Listener

11413.description: Hi! We are currently looking for passionate volunteers who want to give back to the community through the power of reading. Reading Empowers is a non-profit program for students in elementary school to show them the importance of the power of reading, by making reading fun. We engage students in activities and readings, as well as providing them with new books, and goals, every week to show the community that we can make a difference! Our website: http://www.readingempowers.org/ If you are interested in volunteering, please use the link below to fill out an application, and we will contact you with more information. http://www.readingempowers.org/application
11413.title: Reading Empowers - Volunteer with Children / Saturdays / Queens - P.S. 251

07470.description: Help adult students learn English grammar, pronunciation and conversational skills. Supervise ESL classroom activities for approximately 20 adult learners and 12-15 volunteer English Coaches. All learners are recently resettled refugees, almost all are Arabic speakers. Familiarity with English is varied. Some beginners, some adults have a little English. Some of our volunteers have teaching experience, others are not teachers but they helped with our pilot ESL program this fall. Curriculum already set by our Director of Education. All workbooks, materials, and resources available on site. Your job is to coordinate work flow, match learners with volunteer English-speakers (when needed), make sure everyone has properly leveled materials. Adjust/enrich activities where needed. Engage specific learning groups in group mini-lessons as necessary. Help us make it fun!! One student-intern available to help you with administration. Prior experience with adult learners or immigrants helpful. TESOL or related certification highly desirable but not required. Conversational Arabic very helpful. We are looking for someone to supervise Wednesday evenings. The program also runs Saturdays and Sundays from 4-6pm.
07470.title: Lead ESL Instructor
07470.org: GLOBAL EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND ASSISTANCE GERA

07470.description: Develop a 6 to 8 session writing workshop for 8-10 high school aged youth who have recently resettled here from refugee camps in Jordan. Students are enrolled in high school, and have some English conversational skills and attend public high school in Paterson, NJ. Language of origin for our students is Arabic. Most of these students are reading and writing below grade-level and are motivated to \"catch up\" and prepare for college. They currently attend our English program on Saturdays and Sundays. Our English program was designed for adult learners, and we need a writing workshop designed specifically for this age group (ages 14-18). Perfect opportunity for a teacher with ESL training who wants to provide a public service, or a retired teacher who taught high school English or writing. You could develop the curriculum and do the lesson planning and we'll recruit someone else to implement it. Or, if you want to also be there to teach it that's an option too! For more information: www.gera-ngo.org
07470.title: Writing Workshop developer for high-school age youth
07470.org: GLOBAL EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND ASSISTANCE GERA

08901.description: The Court Appointed Special Advocate (CASA) will champion the needs of a child from your community in the local Court system. They will ensure abuse and neglect does not continue at the hands of the system. Spring training is February 26th - March 29th, with a built in make up day in case of snow. Responsibilities: Become a part of the life of a child in foster care. Speak with people in their lives including teachers, therapists and those who care for them. Investigate their school, medical and case worker records. Discover what resources they may need. Establish and communicate recommendations to court professionals. Skills: Complete 30 hours of training (generally completed in one month, during evenings). Attend a 3 hour Court observation. Take part in a swearing in ceremony with a Family Court judge. Commit to advocating for a child's case from inception to conclusion, generally 18 months. About Us: CASA Middlesex is the only child advocacy program where volunteers are appointed by judges to represent a child's best interest. We serve children from our community in Middlesex County who are in foster care. Children with a CASA volunteer spend less time in foster care and have a higher likelihood of finding of finding a permanent home then non - CASA children. We are endorsed by the American Bar Association, National Council of Juvenile and Family Court Judges and the U.S. Department of Justice.
08901.title: Child Advocate
